1. Diversity and inclusion policies: Employers can implement policies that ensure that recruitment, promotions, training, and retention of staff are done without bias or discrimination. 

2. Flexible work arrangements: Employers can provide flexible work arrangements such as part-time work, job sharing, telecommuting, flexible hours, and maternity/paternity leaves. This makes it easier for both men and women to balance work and personal demands. 

3. Equal pay for the same work: Employers can ensure that employees are paid the same wages for jobs that require equal skills, effort, and responsibility, regardless of gender. 

4. Harassment-free workplace: Employers can implement and enforce policies to prevent sexual harassment, bullying and violence at work. 

5. Mentorship and sponsorships: Employers can create mentorship and sponsorship programs to support the development and advancement of women in the workplace. 

6. Women's leadership and networking initiatives: Employers can create women's affinity groups and host leadership events that provide opportunities for women to network, learn new skills, and develop their careers. 

7. Gender-balanced leadership: Employers can ensure that leadership positions are filled with the most qualified candidates, regardless of gender. 

8. Training and awareness programs: Employers can provide training programs that educate employees on gender equality, unconscious bias, and the benefits of diversity and inclusion. 

9. Employee resource groups: Employers can create Employee Resource Groups (ERGs) that support women and other underrepresented groups at work. 

10. Family-friendly policies: Employers can provide family-friendly policies such as on-site daycare, assistance with childcare and eldercare, breastfeeding breaks, and flexible work schedules.
